_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Training provided by the refrigeration contractor

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
man has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) measures to take for ammonia exposure (injured personnel are sent to a medical facility).  Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the fire department for assistance as necessary.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
A Hazard Review has been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and this study has resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Goodman is moving forward with addressing and completing the recommendations. In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.

mpressors CP1  CP4. Booster discharge from Compressors CP5 & CP6 is also sent to the V1 Recirculator to subcool the liquid in the vessel.

The V2 Recirculator pumps low temperature recirculated liquid to the V3 Recirculator and to the -10°F Freezer Evaporators (AU9  AU11) and the -10°F Blast Freezer Evaporators (AU18  AU22). The resulting wet suction generated at the evaporators is returned to the V2 Recirculator. Vapor in the vessel is drawn from the top by Compressors CP1  CP4.

The V3 Recirculator pumps low low temperature recirculated liquid to the -30°F Blast Freezer Evaporators (AU12  AU17). These evaporators return wet suction to the V3 Recirculator. Vapor in the vessel is drawn from the top by Compressors CP5 & CP6.

The Convertible Room Evaporators (AU7 & AU8) receive either high temperature recirculated liquid from the V1 Recirculator or low temperature recirculated liquid from the V2 Recirculator, depending on the type of food product stored in the Convertible Rooms.  These evaporators return wet suction the recirculator vessel that provided the liquid.

All evaporators receive hot gas from the compressors for coil defrost.

Compressors CP1  CP4 draw vapor from the V1 & V2 Recirculators. Compressors CP5 & CP6 draw vapor from the V3 Recirculator. The vapor discharged from Compressors CP5 & CP6 is sent to the V1 Recirculator, while the vapor discharged from Compressors CP1  CP4 is sent to the Condensers (C1 & C2). Discharge from Compressors CP1  CP4 is also routed to all evaporators for hot gas defrost.

At the Condensers (C1 and C2), air (fans) and water (pumps) are used to condense the compressor discharge into high pressure liquid, which then drains to the Thermosyphon Receiver to begin the refrigeration cycle again. 

The system is equipped with an Auto Purger for the removal of non-condensables (i.e. air).

Accidental Release Prevention Program
Goodman has developed an accidental release prevention program for compliance with the CalARP regulat

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies
Goodman is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only the licensed refrigeration contractor is permitted to perform system operations.  Goodman has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In the event of a release, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Goodman is located at 3163 E. Vernon Avenue in Vernon, California.  Ammonia is used in the facilitys refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage of various food products.  The system uses a maximum of 23,000 pounds of ammonia.  A description of how the process operates is presented below:  

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Condensers (C1 and C2) to the Thermosyphon Receiver (V4). The Thermosyphon Receiver provides thermosyphon oil cooling for the Compressors (CP1  CP6). Excess liquid in the Thermosyphon Receiver is sent to the V1 Recirculator.

The V1 Recirculator pumps high temperature recirculated liquid to the V2 Recirculator and the Dock Evaporators (AU1  AU3), Cooler Evaporators (AU4  AU6), and the Palletizing Room Evaporators (AU23 & AU24). Liquid ammonia flowing through the evaporator coils is partially boiled as it absorbs heat from the product and room. The resulting wet suction (liquid/vapor mix) is returned to the V1 Recirculator wherein the liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel (to be reused in the refrigeration cycle) and vapor (high stage suction) is drawn from the top by Co
